AMo REVIEWS


Edward Banks

WASHINGTON DR.. Victor
H. Berry. a graduate Of the
Tuskegee Institute School of
Veterinary Medicine. has been
named staff officer of the labels
and standards section of the US.
Department of Agriculture meat
inspection division.


DR.. Berry was promoted to this
position from St. Paul, Mimi,
where he had served since 1902.

as circuit supervisor OF meat1n-
spection work. He succeeds DR..
]. D. Hatton who has been adj
vanced to the plants and equip
ment section.


The new staff officer was born
and reared in Wichita. Rams. He
came to work for the Depart
ment's meat inspection service in
Milwaukee, Wis.,, in 1855.

Tuo REPORTS weye made to the nation during
the bast week. The long aataited Warren RepoT
concerning the tragedy in Dallas W0S hailed as
y fact,.al and odequate report Of the assassl-
nation of the late President Kennedy by q men,
tnllv unstable person with cO'anaunist1c Team
iugs. Lee Osmuh Mus named as the sole person
connected NTH the fatal shooting.


There woS no evidence to cOn,lec ct Jack Ruby,
the slayer of OsMuld. He acted alone, also.


Despite attempts by wy1ters to make the
tragedy I'm Dallas a sinister plot OF uaenoum
persons, the Warren report should erase
such baseless thoughts.


The second report of national interest MuS
that of j. Edgar Hoover. He unmarked tsnd-
ings of the Federal Bureau of Investigation
cey,.ing the summer race riots in northern
regions.


HIS conclusions shoaO that the riots we're
not linked by a master plot nor we're they
part of any conanaunistic plan. Though some
fringe activities might haze been in OPERATION
before or du1Ing the riots, no evidence IS
available which would shoW that Negroes we're
involved In great numbers.


There IS a tendency among certain groups
I'm our country to blame the communists t0r
all kinds of wrongs or problems. We must
shake loose this easy way of explaining our
oama errors and shortcomings.


SUBSCRIBE ARIZONA TRIBUNE

An exciting and fanciful part Of
the magic of childhood is rapidly
disappearing from the American
scene. The wide avenues of fan
tasy which we're travelled from
the toddling stage to the long
pants days have slowly and al
most completely gone from our
view.


Time was when young children,
and believe. many adults awaited
that rare time when mother,
grandmother, father, aunt, uncle
or an older brother would take
time from the daily routine and
tell ghost story or read scary
tale. Even Little Red Riding
Hood brought squeals of excite
ment though the wee ones
knew 1t by head and heart.


The horrible yet heroic deed
Of the valiant knights of olden
days kept many children in a
place not quite on earth nor in
heaven. How many have recalled
the eerie picture Of a strange
hand holding King Arthur's
sword, the Excalibur out in the
middle of lake7 How many have
recoiled at the sirupy tones of the
wicked stepmother as she led
poor Hansel and Gretel into the
dark forest7


The story Of the three billy
goats even held a bit of romance
for the less sophisticated tastes
Of the youngsters. Jack and all
kinds of giants, Aladdin and his
lamp. Ali Baba. and any number
of fantastic characters kept
childhood one delightful state.


Those horrors of a writer's
imagination, including Franken-
stein, Dracula and the various
werewolves demanded adult re-
actions. but the kids, bless them
refused to succumb to mere fear.


What has become of the big
bad wolves7 Where have the
wicked witches gomez Whence did
the monster Of DR.. Frankenstein
depart7 When did Dracula dis
solver Whittier goest the wolves
that we're Werewolves7


After watching the one-eyed
wide screened monster in our
workroo ! have discovered
why no one is afraid Of those
out OF the world creatures today.
The moviemakers have overdone
the themes. The class F movies
are being shown with monsters
ranging from the pure wolf type
to the dinosaur types Of pre-
historic eras.


During the past few weeks |
have caught portions of monsters
in Japan, werewolves in Tibet
and London, sea monsters, fire
eaters and believe or not a great
dramatic star Claude Rains was
hunting for some in a lost world.


To top off the downfall of mon
sters Casper the kind ghost ap-
peared and this television seas on
initiated The Adams Family.
These sad faced creatures we're
created by Charles Adams.
brilliant cartoonist. They live in
a haunted house, in fact, they are
haunted shells themselves.


Life will never be the same
children are now mis- sing S many
parts of the unreal world which
once could be left to ones imagin-
alton. Now everything is pro-
duced in living sound and the mon
sters are too realistic and COM
monplace to brighten even a man
with a milk toast heart.


KEEP AMERICAS


WAITED TIEAN

Sights and Sounds
ELOtsE BANKS

No Witches?
